Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Refugee Adaptation in the United States, Canada, and Italy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Almost five million refugees have been externally displaced by the Syrian civil war, which began in March 2011. This displacement contributes to the largest international refugee crisis since World War II. Only 1% of those refugees have been resettled to countries where they can restart their lives. This dissertation asks how Syrian refugees make new lives in countries of resettlement by comparing the experience of refugees resettled to the United States, Canada and Italy. War has not only displaced but also declassed the once middle-income families included in this study. These refugees were resettled to each of these countries though they had few if any preexisting ties, did not know the local language, and had skills mismatched to local economies. Most studies of immigration examine outcomes of newcomers years after a cohort's arrival. By contrast, this study focuses on the first 18-24 months after arrival. It considers how Syrian refugees attempt to acquire the skills that matter, how they create new communities, and how their daily lives are shaped by the policy contexts of the countries in which they land. This study has direct, actionable, implications for policy due to its selection of countries with varied resettlement policies for comparison, and its examination of the varied adaptation processes they shape.

This study examines refugees' process of adaptation, defined as the strategies by which newcomers attempt to adjust their family lives, form social relationships, and pursue economic livelihoods in their new setting. This involves refugees finding, together, as families and as an emergent community, new ways of doing things, while retaining aspects of their identity from which they derive a sense of self. This study explores differences in the process of adaptation across political realities of heightened islamophobia, and in the eras of Trump, Trudeau and Pope Francis. This study also looks at country-specific resettlement logics that inform not only the kind of assistance that refugees receive, but also who does the work of resettlement, and the locations where refugees are resettled, near or far from co-ethnics. For this examination, this study uses a combination of ethnographic observation and in-depth interviews. Included in the sample are eighteen Syrian refugee families in New Haven, Connecticut (n=81), five families resettled in and near Toronto, Ontario in Canada (n=25), and six families resettled in the Italian cities of Rome, Todi and Bologna (n=22).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United Nations reports that there are over 25 million refugees registered globally, the most since WWII. Syria is the highest contributing country, with an estimated 6 million people fleeing the war that began in 2011, sparked by the government's brutal response to Arab Spring protestors. Amjad, who was a contractor in Homs, Syria, is one of those who fled. Along with his wife, Rima, and their two toddler sons, he moved to Damascus after witnessing the fatal shootings of his father and 11-year-old sister two weeks apart. He and Rima thought that their departure was temporary, and that they would soon return to the home that they had just begun to build after seven years of saving. Instead, following a car bomb explosion outside of a mosque that almost took Amjad's life, he and his family moved further still to Jordan. There, in July 2012, they registered as refugees.

Their story is not unique. Over the last eight years, hundreds of thousands of Syrians arrived in Jordan, Turkey, and Lebanon. These countries continue to host the vast majority of Syrian refugees. For those who want to move beyond these countries, whose infrastructures are overwhelmed by the influx of refugees, there are two possible solutions: resettlement and asylum. The former occurs when recognized refugees are invited to travel to new countries, and, the latter occurs when immigrants receive refugee status upon applying in new countries. But, what do these two institutional solutions mean for refugees like Amjad and Rima who have been separated from their loved ones by death and displacement, who have little to their name, and whose mother tongue, religion, and ethnicity mark them as minorities?

This project explored resettlement and asylum as continuations of the process of seeking refuge. It draws on over three years of comparative ethnographic fieldwork of Syrian refugee families in their initial years of resettlement in the United States, Canada, and asylum in Germany, countries that have taken the lead on admitting refugees through each of these solutions.*

By following refugees from similar economic and social backgrounds, who arrive within a similar time frame the project shows that national incorporation systems differentially shape their access to resources. The project focuses on the resource of human capital, typically examined in the immigration literature as a measure of skills and capacities upon arrival, and as a crucial determinant of economic mobility. The project finds that human capital can be created, transformed, or destroyed by national incorporation policies' recognition of it and investment in it. Further, it shows that this process differs by gender, as men and women negotiate their expectations for their labor within the constraints of a new context with different demands. I also show how these refugees, who are majority Arab and Muslim, experience discrimination and stigma across these different contexts, and how that too shapes their human capital formation.

In examining how states shape refugees' human capital, the project clarifies whether Syrian newcomers are provided with tools that facilitate their economic mobility and, particularly through language learning, their sense of belonging. It also shows that refugee incorporation policies do not emerge from a vacuum, but rather derive from each countries' historically informed approach to social assistance. In exploring resettlement and asylum as solutions to displacement the projet also shows how states differentially shape the way that refugees integrate as newly arrived racial, ethnic, and religious minorities.

*Also included in the research is the case of Italy, which reveals the importance of a robust economy, and dynamic labor market to any of the outcomes refugees experience.
